title: INLAND PEOPLE: Unbroken bond
text:
By MELANIE C. JOHNSON / CONTRIBUTING WRITER
Published: Oct. 8, 2015 3:41 p.m. INLAND PEOPLE: Unbroken bond Print Photo Share Pin It More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Related article » INLAND PEOPLE Katie Moore
Age: 31
Residence: Orange
Occupation: Founder of the nonprofit ABC Hopes Inc.
Notable: Moore, who grew up in Corona, created a nonprofit that serves adults who have Down syndrome.
HOW TO HELP What: ABC Hopes is a nonprofit that serves individuals with Down syndrome.
Information: To donate, volunteer, or participate in the program visit the ABC Hopes website or the organization's Facebook page.
Katie Moore bonds with her brother Christopher through their mutual love of sports and the playful ribbing that is the standard practice of siblings everywhere.
And although Moore is the big sister, it’s Christopher she looks up to.
“For all of the love he has provided me, I could never repay him,” she said. “He’s my motivation and my inspiration.”
That motivation prompted the Corona native to start a nonprofit in his honor in 2013. ABC Hopes, which is the shortened version of All Because Christopher Hopes, is an organization that serves individuals like Christopher with Down syndrome.
Moore, 31, said the plan is to open it up to other disabilities. The aim of the organization is to raise money to donate to other nonprofits and to demonstrate how capable individuals with Down syndrome are.
She and her dad came up with the idea of a program for adults because after 21, young adults like Christopher, 22, are aged out of school. Parents have to search around for other programs or young adults with disabilities end up sitting around the house all day, she said.
Moore’s parents own citrus groves in Corona and her uncle a farm in Valley Center, near San Diego. Three days a week she takes Christopher and the other program participants to farmers markets in Corona and Anaheim to sell fresh produce from the groves and the farm.
They handle booth set-up and all of the sales themselves and are a hit with customers, Moore said. It’s a job, so they also get paid after each market, giving them a sense of independence to save and buy the things they want, she said.
“People with disabilities want to contribute,” the Orange resident said. “The impact it has on everyday society is huge. It brightens people’s days.”
When they’re not working the farmers markets, she takes Christopher with her to various speaking engagements and community events. Moore helped organize Corona’s host city event for the World Games Special Olympics this summer and recently participated with Christopher in the World Kindness Youth Conference in the city.
The Corona High School alumna, one of five children, said she was 9 years old when Christopher was born, and they’ve been close from day one.
“He and I have always had a special bond,” she said.
They like to watch baseball together, catch movies, and go out to eat.
Moore said her family has always treated Christopher like every other sibling.
“There’s nothing different about him,” she said. “We’ve never treated him like he has a disability. We really focused on making sure he had good social skills.”
Corona resident Becky Sherbanenko, who helps Moore with the organization, said the pair has a special relationship.
“Her commitment to Christopher is her driving force,” Sherbanenko said. “She doesn’t treat him with kid gloves. That’s why he is so social. His family expects him to behave a certain way.”
Sherbanenko, whose daughter went to Corona High with Moore, said her first son had Down syndrome and died at six months old. So when she heard about Moore’s ABC Hopes, she wanted to get involved.
She said she has grown as a result of helping with ABC Hopes.
“It’s been a growth experience for me,” Sherbanenko said. “It’s one of the highlights of my life.”
